column2: What is the difference between procedural programming and object-oriented programming (OOP)?
column3: Procedural programming is based on the concept of procedure calls
column4: where code is executed step by step. OOP is based on objects
column5: which encapsulate data and methods to operate on that data.
column14: Procedural programming is based on the concept of procedure calls  where code is executed step by step. OOP is based on objects  which encapsulate data and methods to operate on that data.

column2: What are the main principles of object-oriented programming?
column3: The main principles of OOP are encapsulation
column4: inheritance
column14: The main principles of OOP are encapsulation  inheritance  polymorphism  and abstraction.

column2: Can you explain the concept of inheritance in OOP?
column3: Inheritance allows a new class to inherit properties and behaviors (methods) from an existing class
column4: promoting code reuse and establishing a relationship between the parent and child classes.
column14: Inheritance allows a new class to inherit properties and behaviors (methods) from an existing class  promoting code reuse and establishing a relationship between the parent and child classes.

column2: What is polymorphism and how does it work in OOP?
column4: Polymorphism allows methods to be used interchangeably in different objects
column5: enabling the same method to perform different functions depending on the object it is called on.
column14: Polymorphism allows methods to be used interchangeably in different objects  enabling the same method to perform different functions depending on the object it is called on.

column2: What is encapsulation and why is it important?
column4: Encapsulation is the bundling of data and the methods that operate on that data within a single unit (class)
column5: restricting direct access to some of an object's components for data protection and integrity.
column14: Encapsulation is the bundling of data and the methods that operate on that data within a single unit (class)  restricting direct access to some of an object's components for data protection and integrity.

column2: What is abstraction in OOP?
column3: Abstraction is the concept of hiding the complex reality while exposing only the necessary parts
column4: allowing for simpler interfaces and focusing on relevant aspects of objects.
column14: Abstraction is the concept of hiding the complex reality while exposing only the necessary parts  allowing for simpler interfaces and focusing on relevant aspects of objects.

column2: Explain the difference between a class and an object.
column3: A class is a blueprint or template for creating objects
column4: and an object is an instance of a class with specific values for its attributes.
column14: A class is a blueprint or template for creating objects  and an object is an instance of a class with specific values for its attributes.

column2: What is a constructor in programming?
column3: A constructor is a special method in a class that initializes new objects
column4: setting initial values for attributes when an object is created.
column14: A constructor is a special method in a class that initializes new objects  setting initial values for attributes when an object is created.

column2: What is the purpose of a destructor in object-oriented programming?
column3: A destructor is a method that is invoked when an object is destroyed
column4: typically used for cleanup
column5: such as freeing resources or closing file handles.
column14: A destructor is a method that is invoked when an object is destroyed  typically used for cleanup  such as freeing resources or closing file handles.

column2: and how is it different from method overriding?
column4: Method overloading is the ability to define multiple methods with the same name but different parameters. Method overriding occurs when a subclass provides a specific implementation of a method already defined in its superclass.
column14: Method overloading is the ability to define multiple methods with the same name but different parameters. Method overriding occurs when a subclass provides a specific implementation of a method already defined in its superclass.

column2: Explain the difference between a static method and an instance method.
column3: A static method belongs to the class and can be called without creating an instance of the class. An instance method belongs to an instance of the class and requires an object to be invoked.
column14: A static method belongs to the class and can be called without creating an instance of the class. An instance method belongs to an instance of the class and requires an object to be invoked.

column2: What are data structures and why are they important in software development?
column4: Data structures are ways of organizing and storing data efficiently. They are important for optimizing performance and ensuring efficient data access and manipulation.
column14: Data structures are ways of organizing and storing data efficiently. They are important for optimizing performance and ensuring efficient data access and manipulation.

column2: What is the difference between an array and a linked list?
column3: An array is a collection of elements stored in contiguous memory locations
column4: while a linked list is a collection of elements (nodes) where each node points to the next one
column14: An array is a collection of elements stored in contiguous memory locations  while a linked list is a collection of elements (nodes) where each node points to the next one  allowing dynamic memory allocation.

column2: What is a stack and how does it work?
column4: A stack is a data structure that follows the Last In
column6: where elements are added and removed from the top of the stack.
column14: A stack is a data structure that follows the Last In  First Out (LIFO) principle  where elements are added and removed from the top of the stack.

column2: What is a queue  and how does it differ from a stack?
column4: A queue is a data structure that follows the First In
column6: where elements are added at the back and removed from the front
column7: unlike a stack which operates on the LIFO principle.
column14: A queue is a data structure that follows the First In  First Out (FIFO) principle  where elements are added at the back and removed from the front  unlike a stack which operates on the LIFO principle.

column2: What is the difference between a hash table and an array?
column3: A hash table stores key-value pairs for fast lookups based on a hash function
column4: while an array is an ordered collection of elements with a fixed index.
column14: A hash table stores key-value pairs for fast lookups based on a hash function  while an array is an ordered collection of elements with a fixed index.

column2: What is a binary tree and what are its types?
column4: A binary tree is a hierarchical data structure where each node has at most two children. Types include full binary trees
column14: A binary tree is a hierarchical data structure where each node has at most two children. Types include full binary trees  complete binary trees  and balanced binary trees.

column2: Can you explain the concept of recursion with an example?
column3: Recursion occurs when a function calls itself. For example
column4: calculating factorials: `factorial(n) = n * factorial(n-1)`
column14: Recursion occurs when a function calls itself. For example  calculating factorials: `factorial(n) = n * factorial(n-1)`  where the base case is `factorial(0) = 1`.

column2: What is dynamic programming and how does it differ from brute-force methods?
column4: Dynamic programming solves problems by breaking them into smaller overlapping subproblems and storing their solutions to avoid redundant calculations. Brute-force methods solve the entire problem without optimization.
column14: Dynamic programming solves problems by breaking them into smaller overlapping subproblems and storing their solutions to avoid redundant calculations. Brute-force methods solve the entire problem without optimization.

column2: What is a database management system (DBMS)?
column3: A DBMS is software that facilitates the creation
column4: management
column14: A DBMS is software that facilitates the creation  management  and manipulation of databases  ensuring data storage  retrieval  and security.

column2: Explain the concept of normalization in a relational database.
column3: Normalization is the process of organizing data in a database to reduce redundancy and dependency by dividing large tables into smaller
column4: related tables.
column14: Normalization is the process of organizing data in a database to reduce redundancy and dependency by dividing large tables into smaller  related tables.

column2: What are the different types of joins in SQL?

column4: LEFT JOIN
column7: which specify how data from two tables is combined based on common columns.
column14: The main types of joins are INNER JOIN  LEFT JOIN  RIGHT JOIN  and FULL JOIN  which specify how data from two tables is combined based on common columns.

column2: What is the difference between a primary key and a foreign key in databases?
column3: A primary key uniquely identifies each record in a table
column4: while a foreign key establishes a relationship between two tables by referring to the primary key in another table.
column14: A primary key uniquely identifies each record in a table  while a foreign key establishes a relationship between two tables by referring to the primary key in another table.

column2: What is the concept of ACID in database transactions?
column3: ACID stands for Atomicity
column4: Consistency
column7: which are principles that guarantee reliable and predictable database transactions.
column14: ACID stands for Atomicity  Consistency  Isolation  and Durability  which are principles that guarantee reliable and predictable database transactions.

column2: Can you explain the difference between SQL and NoSQL databases?
column3: SQL databases are relational and use structured query language for data management
column4: while NoSQL databases are non-relational and are used for unstructured or semi-structured data.
column14: SQL databases are relational and use structured query language for data management  while NoSQL databases are non-relational and are used for unstructured or semi-structured data.

column2: What is a RESTful API?

column6: DELETE) and follows REST principles like statelessness and resource-based operations.
column14: A RESTful API is an interface that allows communication between systems using standard HTTP methods (GET  POST  PUT  DELETE) and follows REST principles like statelessness and resource-based operations.

column2: How does REST differ from SOAP?

column2: What is HTTP and what are its methods (GET , POST,  PUT,  DELETE)?

column2: What are cookies and sessions in web development?
column3: Cookies are small pieces of data stored on the client's browser

column2: What is the Model-View-Controller (MVC) design pattern?
column3: MVC is a software design pattern that separates an application into three components: the model (data)

column5: and the controller (logic that updates the model and view).

column2: What is a version control system (VCS) and why is it important?

column7: and rollback. It's important for managing code changes in software development projects.

column2: What is Git and how do you use it in software development?

column6: and collaborate on software development projects.

column2: What is a pull request in Git?
column3: A pull request is a request to merge changes made in a branch into another branch
column4: typically the main branch

column2: What is the difference between Git merge and Git rebase?
column3: Git merge combines the histories of two branches

column5: while Git rebase moves the entire branch to start from the target branch
column14: Git merge combines the histories of two branches  creating a new commit  while Git rebase moves the entire branch to start from the target branch  resulting in a cleaner  linear history.

column2: What is continuous integration and continuous deployment (CI/CD)?

column2: Can you explain the concept of containerization and how it differs from virtualization?
column3: Containerization isolates applications in lightweight containers that share the same OS kernel
